content.description:
Sit start on the arete behind and left of Mozarts Traverse and pull up onto the arete. Follow the arête up using some feet and right hands on the face. Reach up high over the top and grab a good hold. Mantle up directly and a bit left on sandy holds.

Don't know if anyone has climbed this before.  Let me know if you have info on it.  It's quite grainy and some of the holds are suspect. Could clean up well with some traffic. Good route for the v1-v2 climber to test his mental toughness on the mantle.
content.protection: Two pads and a spotter makes it fairly safe.
content.location: The arête is to your back left if you are standing at the start of Mozarts Traverse.

content.description: Angled slab on the corner of Mozart's Wall.  Clean face climbing with smearing and light hand work.  Great climb for beginners who want to get comfortable with using their feet and don't want a vertical face.  Seasoned climbers enjoy the 'run up'.
content.protection: 3 bolts at the top for anchors.  Shimmy off the top of the formation to a lower ledge to find them.  Recommend backing yourself up on some of the other bolts for light descent.
content.location: Far right corner of Mozart's Wall.  Access to the top is right on the corner.

content.description:
Not as hard as it looks and always impresses the neophytes on Mozart's.

A dance up the arete. A sidepull for the left and pockets for the right, with multiple foot switches, lead to a critical heel hook on the left which allows for a committing throw for the big jug - then do a nervy pull over the top on small put positive enough holds - downclimb using the tree to the right.
content.location: Big boulder directly opposite Mozart's Wall - the southwest edge.

content.description: You've seen the picture of 15 year old Royal Robbins laybacking Nabisco in Converse shoes, right?
content.location: Entrance to Mozart's area, left side. As of the entry date there is a small beehive on the far left side of the flake on the reverse of this boulder.

content.description: Great traverse for building endurance.  The crux is at the far right end.  If you're tired, start R to L to get the crux outta the way first.  If you're fresh, start L to R.
content.location: Route starts at the far left corner of Mozart's Wall and traverses all the way to the right end and turns the corner.  Pretty good landings for 99% of it.

content.description: Good starting climb for the wall.  Crimps and edges.
content.protection: Anchors at top for TR. Use about a 5-8' extension to get your anchor over the edge. Check the bolts, one on the east end is somewhat shady. Anchors can be reached by hiking to the top, either around to the right from the north edge, or scramble up the gully to the left when facing the wall.
content.location: Easiest looking left most route on the wall.  You can tell at the top where everyone else's ropes have run and dug into the rock.

content.description: A decent route that's a bit harder (and more interesting in my opinion) than left hand. I would say second or third easiest on the wall (not counting the arete). It's fairly sustained with decent, if sporadic holds. Focus on getting good positions with your feet and be ready to smear.
content.protection: Use the same anchor as for Left Hand. Just be prepared to swing a little if you come off the wall in the middle.
content.location: Starts about as far left as you can go before getting to the boulder (which is worth scrambling up to get a nice view of the area) and stays left for most of the climb. Once you get to the ledge, traverse right and end at the same spot as Left Hand. See Chris Owen's book "Urban Rock" for more details on the route.

content.description:
This problem is a tad loose but worthwhile if working Quickstep.

Good holds lead you unsuspecting towards the top, the moment of truth is pulling the last couple of moves up very steep stuff.

WARNING: The finishing jug is loose - time will tell if it stays or goes.
content.location: Left of Quickstep (facing away from Mozart's Wall).

content.description: Crux is near the top and right off the ground.  Follow the obvious features pretty much straigt up.  If going over the top bulge, trend left and use the chalked pocket in the roof (5.10).
content.protection: Anchors at top center bolts for TR.  Use about a 5-8' extension to get your anchor over the edge.  Check the bolts, one on the east end is somewhat shady.
content.location: Starts near the COBRA spray paint in the center of the wall.  Use the middle bolt anchors up top.  Walk off on west side.

content.description: Crux is near the top.  Although only rated 5.10a, I thought the top was pretty stiff, but maybe I was a bit off route.
content.protection: Anchors at top for TR.  Use farthest west anchors located down 5' from the top with all the bolts.  It is a three bolt setup with one eye bolt. Use about a 4' extension to get your anchor over the edge.  Check the bolts, the very back one's nuts are a bit loose.
content.location: Starts about 6' right of Amadeus on the well chalked holds.  Holds are more positive here.  Trend diagonally to meet Amadeus for the finish.  Walk off west.

content.description: The crux is near the top were the hands get smooooth.  Face climbing with good footwork.  Really look for the holds and they're all there.
content.protection: Use the bolted anchor straight above the tree on the end.  Not the one at the very end (west side)about 5' down from all the other bolts.
content.location: There is no longer any tree to mark the start of this route. Instead, look for the old chopped bolts just to the right of Center Route and follow them to stay on route.
